Category: PHARMS
Field: Law

                    Text: 
                    Codeine is Schedule II in the United States. This means it is illegal to sell without a DEA license and illegal to buy or possess without a license or prescription. Products such as Tylenol II-IV, which contain less than 90 mg codeine per dosage unit, are Schedule III. Products with less than 200 milligrams per 100 grams (or milliters) of dosage unit are Schedule V and are much less restricted. In January 2014, the FDA announced that they were going to begin new, additional enforcement against unapproved prescription drugs in the US that contain codeine. See https://www.federalregister.gov/articles/2014/01/10/2014-00257/unapproved-and-misbranded-oral-and-injectable-drugs-labeled-for-prescription-use-containing-codeine#print_view. Apparently drug manufacturers had been producing new, commercially-available compounded products that had not gone through the FDA's rigorous new product approval process.

U.S. STATE LAW #


                    Context: 
                    This chunk appears in a section detailing the legal status of codeine, following a summary of its classification under U.S. federal law. It explains how codeine is scheduled according to the amount in products, describes the implications for legal sale and possession, and references recent FDA enforcement actions. This section precedes state-by-state variations in codeine law and is part of a broader document presenting legal information about codeine in the U.S. and internationally.

                    Text: 
                    U.S. STATE LAW #

Thanks to a submitter, we learned in January 2017 that we had missed that around twelve states in the U.S. offer low dose codeine (mostly as cough syrup) at some pharmacies without prescription. The preparations fall under Schedule V because of their low dose per unit and low total amount per package. We have been able to confirm most of them, but the list might include Arkansas, Florida, Illinois, Indiana, Iowa, Georgia, North Carolina, New Mexico, Mississippi, Massachusetts, and Pennsylvania.

Arkansas #

Arkansas allows pharmacists to sell low dose codeine cough syrup without a prescription. See https://arkansas.magellanrx.com/provider/docs/rxinfo/otclist.pdf (thanks E) (last updated Feb 1 2017)

Florida #

Florida might allows pharmacists to sell low dose codeine products without prescription. (unconfirmed) (last updated Feb 1 2017)

Georgia #

                    North Carolina #

North Carolina has legal over the counter (OTC) sales of codeine, including the brand Cheratussin (10mg codeine + 100mg guaifenesin per 5ml). "A Schedule V substance may be sold at retail without a prescription only by a registered pharmacist and no other person, agent or employee may sell a Schedule V substance even if under the direct supervision of a pharmacist." See http://www.ncga.state.nc.us/enactedlegislation/statutes/html/byarticle/chapter_90/article_5.html. (thanks E) (last updated Jan 31 2017)

Ohio #

Ohio seems to exempt low dose codeine products from their main criminal penalty rules, which probably allows pharmacists to offer them for sale. See http://codes.ohio.gov/orc/3719. (thanks E) (last updated Feb 1 2017)

Pennsylvania #

                    Pennsylvania #

Pennsylvania allows the sale by pharmacists low dose codeine products, along with other Schedule V drugs (28 * 25.57. Nonprescription orders.) . See http://www.health.pa.gov/facilities/Consumers/Health%20Facilities/Home%20Health%20Services%20and%20Hospices/DDC/Laws/Code_28.pdf. (thanks E) (last updated Jan 31 2017)

If you have information about the legal status of this substance in any other U.S. state, please let us know.

INTERNATIONAL LAW #

Australia #

Beginning February 2018, codeine can no longer be purchased over the counter and is prescription only, although a there is an over the counter cough syrup called "Rikodeine" which contains Dihydrocodeine. See https://www.jobfit.com.au/2018/01/30/new-codeine-laws/. (thanks Ultra) (last updated Jul 11 2018)

Bahamas #

Products containing low to moderate doses of codeine are available for puchase over-the-counter in the Bahamas. One product, for example, is sold containing 8 mg codeine to 400 mg aspirin.

Canada #

Codeine is Schedule I in Canada. Products containing low quantities of codeine (such as Tylenol 1) can be purchased over-the-counter, but products with higher quantities require a prescription. As of July 2018, we're told that there seem to be more controls on non-prescription codeine sales by pharmacies, with many often reporting they are out of stock, some pharmacies refusing sales, and others requiring registering with the pharmacy to purchase codeine in Canada. (Last updated July 11 2018)

                    Text: 
                    Codeine has a complicated legal status in the Netherlands. Codeine is available both with and without a prescription. The preparation, possession, adaption, delivery, providing and transport, of pure codeine is prohibited, because itâ€™s scheduled on 'list I' of the 'Opium Law' (List I drugs are considered hard drugs). Conversely, low-dose codeine cough syrup (0.5 mg codeine phosphate/ml) is available without prescription, and is unregulated. Other preparations are available with a prescription only, but are not regulated by the Opium Law. Prescription preparations of codeine with (with more than 100 mg codeine in each dose and/or prescription preparations with a concentration over 2.5% codeine), are regulated by the Opium Law. Prescriptions for preparations with this quantity of codeine require to comply with special requirements of an Opium-Law-prescription. Possession of small quantities (for personal use) of prohibited substances is typically not prosecuted. Recreational use of

                    Thailand #

Codeine-containing pain relievers such as Tylenol-2's are now reportedly controlled in Thailand, and are now difficult to find for sale by pharmacists without a prescription. (thanks CP,A) (last updated Jun 2010)

Vietnam #

Codeine-containing pain relievers such as Efferalgan (an effervescent) are widely available without prescription over the counter at street pharmacies throughout Vietnam. As of June 2011, 100 tablets of 30mg codeine/500mg acetaminophen cost around $15USD. (thanks W, MPA) (last updated June 24 2011)

                    Text: 
                    U.K. #

Codeine is Schedule II/Class b in the U.K., making it illegal to buy or possess without a prescription. Products containing small amounts of codeine (such as Tylenol w/codeine, Feminax (8 mg), and Solpadeine Max or Neurofen Plus (12.5 mg)) are available over-the-counter without prescription. Codeine Linctus (200ml 15mg/5ml) are available in some pharmacies with no prescription needed and can also be purchased via amazon.co.uk from a UK-based online pharmacy, requiring answers to questions by email to fill the order. (thanks c) (last updated Jan 19 2012)

Ukraine #

Although Russia has made codeine a prescription medication in Russia in 2012, the law has not yet changed in the Ukraine. See http://www.rt.com/news/prime-time/codeine-drug-law-russia-845/. (thanks e) (last updated Jul 19, 2012)

United Kingdom #

                    Text: 
                    United Kingdom #

Some availability of codeine without prescription from pharmacies, but often requires asking about it. Weak codeine + paracetamol 8/500 tablets are reportedly easier to get, but it difficult to find pharmachemists ('chemists' in British English) who will sell codeine without paracetamol, often as "codeine linctus". (thanks K, Z) (last updated Nov 25 2017)

Venezuela #

Codeine-containing product called Preveral available over-the-counter in Venezuela. (unconfirmed) (thanks M)

If you have information about the legal status of this substance in any other country, please let us know.
